com.paypal.merchant.sdk
Class PayPalHereSDK

java.lang.Object
  com.paypal.merchant.sdk.PayPalHereSDK

public final class PayPalHereSDK
extends Object

The main object through which you can interact with PayPal Services and associated hardware devices
such as card readers and chip & pin devices.

There are three main APIs you can access:

CardReaderManager - Allows interaction with devices such as swipers and Bluetooth Chip & Pin devices
TransactionManager - Used to take payments, do refunds.
MerchantManager - Allows access of merchant info and discovering things like what users are checked
into your store and accepting payments from the same.

***** USING THE SDK *****

Here's how to quickly get up and running with the SDK:

1) Init the SDK:

Before using the PayPalHereSDK you must init it. You can do that by calling:

PalPalHereSDK.init(myApplication, PayPalHereSDK.Sandbox);


2) Log in & provide Merchant Credentials:

Setting up Merchant Credentials is one of the fundamental steps needed to be able to use the APIs
defined by this SDK.
The APIs you will discover through the various interfaces in this SDK all do some work on behalf of
an active merchant and it is the application's responsibility to provide the credentials to access the merchant info.
From the application's point of view this entails two smaller steps:
a) Perform the OAuth process to interface with PayPalAccess and retrieve an access token, refresh url & expiry
for the user(merchant). You would typically do this by making the user log in into your system everytime the app is opened
by the user

b) Based on the access token, refresh url and expiry values create a new Credentials object and initialize
the setting up of an active merchant. Look at this @Credentials for documentation on how to create
and initialize this object.
Once this step is completed the SDK is ready for other APIs to be called by the app. You, as a developer, should
ensure that this step is completed every time the user enters the application and provide meaningful feedback to the
user if errors are encountered during this stage.
You can also look at the sample app and re-use the parts of OAuthLoginActivity to help with your implementation.

3) Take a payment:
The SDK provides consistent and easy to use APIs to take payments on behalf of the merchant in many different ways

As an example: to request payment for a fixed amount you can use the following:
PayPalHereSDK.getTransactionManager().beginPayment(new BigDecimal("42.50")); PayPalHereSDK.getTransactionManager().finalizePayment(PaymentType.CARD_READER, callbackHandler);

This API above simply takes in the amount to be charged, the mode of payment (credit card using a card reader device)
and a callback handler that will be notified of status

There are additional methods in TransactionManager to take cash payments, card not present payments, payments from
users who are checked into you store, etc. Please see the documentation in TransactionManager

In order to provide your users with optimal user experience it is important that your application defines
and implements the callback APIs appropriately. For example, when attempting to take a payment there will be events
that your application needs to handle. One such event is NEED_PIN. This callback from the SDK to your
app indicates that the SDK requires an action to be completed by the merchant/seller. It is the application's
responsibility to provide a meaningful UI so that the user knows he/she needs to perform an action. In this case
the user (merchant/seller) will ask the customer to enter a PIN on the ChipAndPin Reader's Pinpad.

These APIs are primarily available through the following interfaces:
TransactionListener For receiving events related to the payment you are attempting.
CardReaderListener For receiving events related to the card reading hardware you are
using (swipers, C&P readers)

Field Detail

Sandbox

public static String Sandbox
Passed into init(), 'Sandbox' is used to init the SDK against the PayPal Sandbox (test) servers.

Live

public static String Live
Passed into init(), 'Live' is used to init the SDK against the PayPal Live service.

sIsSDKInitialized

protected static boolean sIsSDKInitialized
Method Detail

init

public static void init(android.content.Context appContext,
                        String serverName)
Call to init the SDK

Parameters:
appContext - Your Android Application object. The context will be used to init some portions of the SDK
serverName -
This is usually set to one of two values. PayPalHereSDK.Sandbox
or PayPalHereSDK.Live. This field exists to allow developers to
work in development mode during which you can test everything against
a sandbox and when the app is ready switch this to point to Live
NOTE: Setting this to the right value is critical; be careful to ensure that
your shipping app doesn't have this value set to Sandbox!

setCredentials

public static void setCredentials(Credentials credentials,
                                  DefaultResponseHandler<Merchant,PPError<MerchantManager.MerchantErrors>> defaultResponseHandler)
Set the credentials object to be able to use the PayPal Services. See the Credentials object defined
in the domain namespace for detailed notes on creating these objects.
Note that the SDK keeps track of only one credentials object. If this API is invoked multiple times then
the older value will get rewritten.

Parameters:
credentials - - this is the credentials object that is being set as active for the SDK

defaultResponseHandler - - setCredentials is an asynchronous API and will return immediately
and this handler interface will be invoked when the operation is completed successfully or when a failure
is encountered

registerAuthenticationListener

public static void registerAuthenticationListener(AuthenticationListener listener)
Register an AuthenticationListener with the SDK. AuthenticationListener objects are notified when/if a token becomes invalid.

Parameters:
listener - AuthenticationListener instance

unregisterAuthenticationListener

public static void unregisterAuthenticationListener(AuthenticationListener listener)
Unregister an AuthenticationListener from the SDK.

Parameters:
listener - AuthenticationListener instance

notifyAuthenticationListeners

public static void notifyAuthenticationListeners()
Notifies all listeners of that the Credential token has been found invalid.

getCardReaderManager

public static CardReaderManager getCardReaderManager()
Get an instance to the CardReaderManager object that can be used to interface with the CardReaders
connected to the PayPalHereSDK

Returns:
CardReaderManager

getTransactionManager

public static TransactionManager getTransactionManager()
Get an instance to the TransactionManager object that allows you to take payments, set signatures, and
process refunds.

Returns:
TransactionManager

getMerchantManager

public static MerchantManager getMerchantManager()
Get an instance to the MerchantProfileManager object that allows you to discover your merchant info, access
merchant settings, and fetch information such as what PayPal users are checked into your store.

Returns:
MerchantManager

getAvailableServers

public static String[] getAvailableServers()
Returns the service names you can connect to ("Live", "Stage2pph03", etc)
By default the list of available servers is limited to Live & Sandbox. Apps can set their own list of servers to point to as well using the setOptionalServerList.

Returns:
A string array containing aliases for the available servers

getAllConfiguredServersMap

public static HashMap<String,String> getAllConfiguredServersMap()
Returns a list of all the servers the SDK knows about. It returns them in the form of a HasMap. The HashMap's key is the name of the service, the value is the server's base URL.

Returns:
A HashMap containing the mapping of server names to base URLs.

setServerName

public static void setServerName(String serverName)
Switch to one of the servers from the getAvailableServers list. Pass in the server name (not the url) and the SDK will now send payment and other requests to that backend service.

Parameters:
serverName - A server name from the getAvailableServers list.

getCurrentServer

public static String getCurrentServer()
Returns the current service name.

Returns:
returns the name of the current service.

setOptionalServerList

public static void setOptionalServerList(String serverListJSON)
Use this API to set your own list of optional servers. Note that this simply allows you to point us to base urls for various stages. Internally, we determine the port number to use for different APIs based on some magic rules.

Parameters:
serverListJSON - A json formatted array of servers. Please see the sample applicaiton for the format.
